questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a physical property of water?
questions.explanation: Although water can conduct electricity, this is not a fundamental physical property studied in basic hydraulics.

questions.question: What unit is used to measure pressure in the International System?
questions.explanation: The Pascal (Pa) equals N/m² and is the pressure unit in SI.

questions.question: What is the approximate density of water at 4°C?
questions.explanation: At 4°C, water has its maximum density: 1000 kg/m³.

questions.question: What fluid property relates to internal resistance to flow?
questions.explanation: Viscosity measures the resistance to sliding between fluid layers.

questions.question: Which of the following instruments is used to measure pressure?
questions.explanation: The manometer is an instrument designed to measure confined fluid pressure.

questions.question: What does the dimensionless Reynolds number represent?
options: Relationship between inertial and viscous forces
Relationship between area and flow rate
questions.explanation: Reynolds is used to classify the type of flow (laminar or turbulent).

questions.question: What unit system is based on meter, kilogram, and second?
questions.explanation: The SI is based on m, kg, s, and is the standard system used in hydraulics.

questions.question: What property of water allows insects to walk on it?
questions.explanation: Surface tension forms a 'film' that resists light external forces.

questions.question: What unit represents specific weight?
questions.explanation: Specific weight is weight per unit volume (N/m³).

questions.question: What physical property of water is mainly affected by temperature?
questions.explanation: Water viscosity decreases as temperature increases.

unit2.description: Hydrostatics studies fluids at rest and the forces acting on them. This unit covers the fundamental concepts of pressure in static fluids, forces on submerged surfaces, and buoyancy principles.
topics: Hydrostatic pressure and its fundamental properties
unit2.simulationsSubtitle: Practice with simulations that will help you visualize the concepts
unit2.simulationDescription: Interactive simulation to better understand this topic
objectives: Understand the fundamental principles of hydrostatics
Apply principles of buoyancy and stability

unit3.description: Hydrodynamics studies the behavior of fluids in motion. This unit explores the principles of mass and energy conservation in flows, the continuity equation, Bernoulli's principle, and their practical applications in engineering.
topics: Continuity equation and conservation of mass
Types of flow: laminar and turbulent

unit4.description: This unit explores the fundamental concepts of pressure in fluids, density, and Archimedes' principle. Learn how objects interact with fluids, why some float and others sink, and how pressure varies with depth.
topics: Hydrostatic pressure and its relationship with depth
Density and specific weight of fluids
Design of submarines and floating structures

fluidFlowSimulation.title: Fluid Flow
fluidFlowSimulation.observation1: • When area decreases, velocity increases (Continuity Equation)
fluidFlowSimulation.observation2: • Where velocity increases, pressure decreases (Bernoulli's Principle)
fluidFlowSimulation.observation3: • The total energy of the fluid is conserved throughout the flow
fluidFlowSimulation.continuityDescription: Flow rate (Q) remains constant in incompressible flow
fluidFlowSimulation.bernoulliFormula: P₁ + ½pv₁² + pgh₁ = P₂ + ½pv₂² + pgh₂
fluidFlowSimulation.bernoulliDescription: The sum of static, dynamic, and potential pressure is conserved
fluidFlowSimulation.volumetricDescription: Q = Flow rate (m³/s), A = Area (m²), v = Velocity (m/s)

underPressureSimulation.title: Under Pressure
underPressureSimulation.observation2: • Denser fluids generate greater pressure at the same depth
underPressureSimulation.observation3: • An object floats when the buoyant force exceeds its weight
underPressureSimulation.observation4: • Pressure acts equally in all directions
